risk_factors.reasoning: He is an 18-year-old male who has already been arrested 10 times, which suggests a higher risk of rearrest
As a White male, he may be considered a vulnerable group in the eyes of law enforcement and judges, increasing his likelihood of rearrest
Although not explicitly stated, it can be inferred that his racial identity as White may make him more susceptible to arrest due to historical biases and discriminatory practices
Living with both biological parents in a household of size 4, in an urban area, suggests a high level of stability and support which could reduce his likelihood of rearrest
He is single and has never been married, which may indicate less opportunity for social support or community resources that could help him avoid arrest
Having held only one job during the year suggests a lack of stability in his life, increasing his risk of re-offending
Not having a GED certificate or enrolled in college indicates a possible lack of access to education and training programs which could help him rehabilitate
Although he has not felt depressed over the past month, his history with drugs (marijuana and cocaine) may suggest some level of vulnerability to substance abuse or addiction
Having only one job during the year indicates a lack of economic stability which could increase his risk of re-offending
Living alone in an urban area with no family support may indicate stress and increased vulnerability to arrest
His consideration that God has something to do with what happens to him personally suggests a high level of faith which could be protective against re-offending
